> But Spring is really built to wire together plain Java classes, so you
> should be able to test 99% of your application without knowing about
> Spring at all.

I definitely recommend not to use Spring in the unit tests unless
there's no other way. In one of our current project some of the
developers thought it was a good idea to keep Spring in the unit tests
too and now we regret it. It makes the unit test environment messy and
makes reading the tests harder as the wiring and Dependency Injection
is done in Spring. It seems much cleaner to me if the injections are
done in the test code and furthermore using mocks don't contradict
with it.

> > i have to test stored procedures called from hibernate persisters over
> > spring framework.
> 
> Ignore everything except the stored procedures. To test those, you can
> use something like DbUnit and call the stored procedures from JDBC.

We're currently looking at using DbUnit because the data that we use
to test our stored procedure start to change as we change the schema
and database. Soon, we're going to introduce a test database and
DbUnit's Ant task to create and delete the necessary data.
